title: Exciting brands, dated corporate culture
text: Pros Great benefits, PTO policy, summer Fridays. Fun activities always going on in NYHQ. Great things going on within each brand, but very hard to feel part of it when you work in the shared services department. People are friendly and the office is casual. The new renovated floors are great workspaces if you're lucky enough to be in one. Cons Low salaries, very dated corporate culture. Job titles and hierarchy count for everything. People in senior positions have worked here for 10-20 years and are very protective of their VP titles, status and corner offices. Lots of reporting deadlines and repetitive work. Advice to Management Delegation is empowering!! Break down the rigid lines of hierarchy, remove closed door meetings and communicate information more frequently from the top down. Your teams will shine when you give them to power to do so! Bob is a great new leader so hopefully things will change.

title: Viacom, Company At The Crossroads
text: Pros The company has great benefits and takes care of its employees. Firm believer in diversity when it comes to hiring. Forward thinking and fun work environment that promotes and rewards creativity. Cons The company is great to its employees... until the numbers don't add up and the managers don't hit their budgets. Then the layoffs come and it can be brutal. Diversity in the work place does not include age. Once you hit 50 your days are numbered. There's never been a retirement party at Viacom. NIckelodeon is on firm ground, but the rest of their cable networks are on thin ice. The rise of Netflix, Hulu and the cord cutting amongst their former core audience has created a downward spiral, not helped by the poor programming development over the past decade across the board. The current CEO has two years to turn it around. Advice to Management CEO is making all the right decisions with the exception of tossing people out just because they've been with the company too long. Yes some need to go, but others have valuable experience that can't be replaced.

title: Pay your employees market value!!!!
text: Pros Fun brands to work for, work life balance is great, excellent health insurance, lots of fun "soft" perks like access to Paramount Movies before they're in theaters. It's a great place to start a career. Cons Not a great place for your career to develop after reaching middle management level. It's very cliquish, as a result, promotions are often due to who you're friends with rather than your performance. However really the biggest con of working at Viacom is the deplorable salary. Even when you consider bonuses, Viacom's pay is SIGNIFICANTLY lower than other media companies. Upon leaving for another media company, I earned a 40% raise, even though the new role was for a lower title. If Viacom wants to retain talent it works so hard to develop in entry level roles, they need to pay better. Advice to Management Stop spending thousands of dollars on Jacques Torres chocolate to give to employees chocolate on Valentines day, and other ridiculously unnecessary and expensive "soft" perks, and pay employees what they deserve.

Cons The drastic changes over the last couple of years have made job stability there hard to predict. They laid off hundreds of people world wide last summer, and laid off more in some of the brands earlier this year. These lay offs come with no warning, and it is scary to think you can just wake up one day at Viacom, and you will be laid off. I understand it is a corporation, but at least sometimes, you see the lay offs coming in other corporate settings so you can play ahead. You never see them coming at Viacom. Advice to Management A more robust and structured mentor system. They should only recruit mentors that are willing and able to dedicate time to the program.
